item.title: Typhoon slams into northeastern Philippines
item.description: MANILA, Philippines (AP) - A fast-moving typhoon slammed into the northeastern Philippines on Sunday, sparking warnings of possible landslides, flash floods and storm surges. Typhoon Kalmaegi, with sustained winds of 130 kilometers per hour (81 miles per hour) and gusts of 160 kph (99 mph), blew into the boundary of Cagayan and Isabela provinces with no immediate reports of casualties. It was forecast to barrel northwestward through the mountainous north at 22 kph (14 mph) before blowing out Tuesday into the South China Sea, government forecasters said. Residents in at least nine northern provinces, which have been drenched by days of rains, were warned to take precautions and stay away from already soggy mountainsides and swollen rivers. Classes have been suspended in cities and provinces that are expected to be swamped by floodwaters overnight or on Monday. The storm has been blamed for enhancing monsoon winds that whipped up big waves and caused a stalled ferry to sink in the central Philippines late Saturday. Cargo and passenger ships plucked at least 110 survivors from the rough waters and recovered three bodies after the ferry sank. Kalmaegi, the Korean word for seagull, is the 12th weather disturbance to batter the Philippines this year. The calamity-prone archipelago is lashed by about 20 storms and typhoons every year, each requiring major disaster-mitigation preparations. The Department of Social Welfare and Development said it has pre-positioned 3,000 family food packs in northern communities that may be isolated by the storm. About 100,000 other such food packs have been prepared in case of wider typhoon-wrought calamity. Army and police forces, backed by rubber boats, trucks and air force helicopters, have been put on standby for possible search and rescue operations.

item.description: Islamic State militants fighting in Iraq and Syria released a video on Saturday which purported to show the beheading of British aid worker David Haines.

item.description: At least 17 people were killed when a guest house under construction at the Lagos headquarters of one of Nigeria's best-known Christian evangelical pastors collapsed, rescue officials said on Saturday.

item.title: Iraq PM says will protect civilians after US-Iraq air strikes against Islamic States
item.description: Iraq's Shi'ite Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi said on Saturday that he had ordered his air force to halt strikes on civilians, following attacks by both Iraqi and US jets in large areas of the country held by Islamic State fighters.

item.title: Thousands march for UK as Scotland vote nears
item.description: Thousands of members of the Protestant Orange order marched through Edinburgh on Saturday in a show of strength against Scottish independence, as campaigning ahead of the referendum entered its final weekend.

item.title: Families of beheaded US reporters warned not to pay ransoms
item.description: The families of two journalists beheaded by Islamic State jihadists were both warned by US government officials they could face prosecution if they raised a ransom for their release.

item.title: Egypt on frontline in fight against IS militants, says John Kerry
item.description: US Secretary of State John Kerry on Saturday said that Egypt was on the "frontline of fighting terrorism" as he met Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi in his effort to build a broad coalition against Islamic State terrorists who have seized large chunks of land in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Fishermen's body found washed ashore off Sri Lankan coast
item.description: The body of one of thethree Tamil Nadu fishermen, who went missing after they put to sea on August 25, has been washed ashore in Velvattithurai coast off Sri Lanka, a senior functionary of a local Fishermen's Association on Saturday said.

item.title: India keen to enhance cooperation with Vietnam
item.description: India is looking to enhance cooperation with Vietnam in defence, security and political arena as there is immense potential for bilateral engagement between the two nations, President Pranab Mukherjee said on Saturday.

item.title: Sheikh Hasina, Narendra Modi likely to meet on UNGA sidelines: Bangladesh official
item.description: Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina is expected to hold first meeting with her Indian counterpart Narendra Modi on September 27 on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) in New York, a foreign ministry official said on Saturday.

item.title: US wants to cut economic ties between EU and Russia: Lavrov
item.description: The United States is using the Ukraine crisis to cut economic ties between the EU and Russia and force Europe to pay more for its gas, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said on Saturday.

item.title: Pope Francis marks 100 years from start of WWI
item.description: Pope Francis on Saturday denounced those who profit from the "madness" of war at a ceremony in the north west of Italy to mark the 100th anniversary of the beginning of World War I.

item.title: SCO summit paves way for entry of India: Chinese experts
item.description: India has a very good chance of being inducted into Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) along with Pakistan, a development which will strengthen anti-terrorism campaign in the region, Chinese experts believe.

item.title: Malaysian girl, 8, dies after being flung from Australian ride
item.description: Australian authorities are investigating the death of a Malaysian girl who was flung "like a doll" from a spinning ride at the Royal Adelaide Show where showgoers laid flowers for her Saturday.

item.title: France bristles as Netflix advances in Europe
item.description: Netflix is tapping into six new markets on Monday hoping to gain a big subscriber base around Europe, but is facing a frosty welcome in France. Well-established French competitors are trying to head off a Netflix wave, the government wants oversight and the cinema industry wants Netflix to invest heavily in French productions.

item.title: Combatting Islamic State not US fight alone: Obama
item.description: President Barack Obama is distinguishing the military campaign against Islamic State militants from the decade-long wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. He says the fight must avoid what he calls mistakes of the past.

item.title: China urges central Asian neighbours to step up extremism fight
item.description: China's President Xi Jinping urged Central Asian states to step up the fight against religious extremism and cyber terrorism, state media said, as Beijing reaches for help across its borders in addressing security concerns in its restive Xinjiang region.

item.title: Evolutionary approach can save earth: Scientists
item.description: Evolutionary thinking is not just about the past anymore. It is about the present and the future and addressing societal challenges such as food security, emerging diseases and bio-diversity loss in a sustainable way, says a significant study.

item.title: Ferguson video shows witness raising hands in air
item.description: Cellphone video that shows a witness raising his hands in the air immediately after the fatal shooting of a black 18-year-old by a white police officer in Missouri appears to support previous accounts and could bolster arguments that the young man was surrendering when he was shot, legal experts said Friday.

item.title: Japan pushes North Korea to resolve abductions
item.description: Japan's prime minister turned up the pressure on North Korea on Saturday to answer questions over the fate of possibly hundreds of Japanese citizens believed to have been abducted by the North's agents in the 1970s and '80s.

item.title: Ukraine PM says country still in "state of war"
item.description: Ukraine is "still in a state of war" with neighboring Russia despite a cease-fire between Kiev's forces and Moscow-backed rebels in the east, the country's prime minister said on Saturday shortly after a second convoy of Russian trucks rolled into Ukraine.

item.title: Iraq PM orders halt to shelling of civilian areas
item.description: Iraq's prime minister said on Saturday that he has ordered the army to stop shelling populated areas held by militants in order to spare the lives of "innocent victims" as the armed forces struggle to retake cities and towns seized by the Islamic State extremist group this summer.

item.title: Pope urges world to shed apathy toward new threats
item.description: Pope Francis urged the world on Saturday to shed its apathy in the face of what he sees as a third world war, intoning "war is madness" at the foot of a Fascist-era monument to soldiers killed in World War I.

item.title: Vladimir Putin trying to destroy Ukraine, says its PM
item.description: Ukraine's prime minister said on Saturday Russian President Vladimir Putin aimed to destroy Ukraine as an independent country and said only NATO could defend the ex-Soviet republic from external aggression.

item.title: Islamic State's Twitter silence raises questions
item.description: Several accounts affiliated with the militant group appear to have gone dormant, according to US government sources.

item.title: 'New' Scots vote crucial to independence result
item.description: In the heartland of Scotland's Asian community, support for independence from United Kingdom is strong as Thursday's referendum nears.

item.title: China issues heavy rain, typhoon alert
item.description: China's National Meteorological Centre (NMC) on Saturday issued an alert for heavy rain and typhoon.

item.title: Australian Radio station prank leads to nurse's death, donates USD 550,000 to her family
item.description: An Australian radio station, which aired a prank on a nurse who took her life after the broadcast has donated USD 550,000 to her family.

item.title: Barack Obama points to 'silver lining' in IS mayhem in the region
item.description: US President Barack Obama has pointed to a "silver lining" in the violence wrought by the Islamic State.

item.title: Netherlands deploys more experts to probe MH17 crash
item.description: The Dutch government has decided to send more experts to Ukraine to investigate the cause of Malaysia Airline flight MH17's crash.

item.title: Barack Obama asks Americans to devote themselves to social service
item.description: Barack Obama said he would not be in the position he is now if it was not for service to others.

item.title: US lawmaker seeks suspension of visa-free travel for Europeans
item.description: Democratic lawmaker sought an immediate suspension of visa-free travel to the US from countries like Britain, Germany and France.

item.title: Senator applauds 'progress' made in Indo-US ties in 100 days
item.description: A top American Senator has applauded the progress made in the Indo-US relationship in the first 100 days of the Narendra Modi government, which the lawmaker said would provide "new energy" and "important momentum" ahead of the Indian prime minister visit to America.

item.title: US opposes Iran role in anti-Islamic State coalition
item.description: US Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday it was "not appropriate" for Iran to join talks on confronting Islamic State militants, as he appeared to play down how fast countries can commit to force or other steps in an emerging coalition.

item.title: UN names new envoy for West Africa
item.description: Ban Ki-moon appointed Mohammed Ibn Chambas of Ghana as his special representative and head of the UN Office for West Africa

item.title: Wild fire in Spain forces 1,500 to evacuate to safety
item.description: Around 1,500 people have been evacuated from their homes as the result of a wild fire which has affected the Montgo national park.

item.title: Indian pharmacologist charged with smuggling fake drugs
item.description: An Indian pharmacologist has been charged with smuggling four million misbranded and counterfeit pharmaceuticals into the US.

item.title: Nigeria's military claims success against Boko Haram
item.description: Nigeria's military claimed to have routed Boko Haram militants near the Borno state capital Maiduguri.

item.title: International diamond thief detained in Switzerland: Interpol
item.description: A Chinese jewellery thief accused of stealing millions of dollars worth of diamonds across the world has been arrested in Switzerland.

item.title: Ukraine warns of painful winter due to Russian gas cut
item.description: Russia in June halted gas exports to Ukraine after Kiev balked at paying higher prices that Moscow demanded in the wake of the February ouster of a Kremlin-backed president.

item.title: Obama to discuss Ebola response with top medical experts
item.description: President Barack Obama will meet leading US medical experts next week as he considers how to follow through on his pledge to step up aid to Africa over the Ebola epidemic.

item.title: US intensifies sanctions on Russia over Ukraine
item.description: The United States hit Russia's largest bank, a major arms maker and arctic, deepwater and shale exploration by its biggest oil companies with new sanctions on Friday to punish Moscow for its intervention in Ukraine.

item.title: UK offers Scotland more autonomy ahead of vote
item.description: The British government plans to offer Scotland more financial autonomy in the coming days as polls predict a very close vote in the upcoming referendum on Scottish independence.

item.title: Pakistan remains China's priority: President Xi Jinping
item.description: Xi was due to visit Pakistan on Sunday as part of his first South Asia trip which included Sri Lanka and India.

item.title: Scottish referendum campaign switches focus to Glasgow
item.description: Campaigners for and against Scotland's independence focused their efforts on Glasgow on Friday as separatist leader Alex Salmond said he was confident of victory despite a new poll showing the pro-UK campaign recovering lost ground.

item.title: China to fast-track prosecution of terrorists, extremists
item.description: Chinese prosecutors have been asked to fast-track cases involving terrorists, religious extremists and manufacturers of firearms.

item.title: Australia upgrades national terror alert
item.description: Australia raised the national terrorism public alert after receiving advice from the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

item.title: China unlikely to join Obama's anti-ISIS coalition: Report
item.description: Though facing militancy in its restive Xinjiang province, China is unlikely to join the US- led campaign against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria but will provide moral support, the state media reported on Friday.

item.title: Prison suicide rate rises in Britain
item.description: The number of prisoners who took their own lives in England and Wales from 2013-14 increased by 64 per cent.

item.title: MH17 crash site still unsafe for investigators: Dutch
item.description: The site where flight MH17 crashed is unsafe for investigators to resume the recovery of victims' remains, Dutch Defence Minister said.

item.title: White House insists Barack Obama authorized to strike IS
item.description: The White House insisted that Barack Obama was authorized to strike the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: 45 Fijian peacekeepers freed in Syria, says UN
item.description: Al-Qaeda-linked militants released 45 Fijian peacekeepers captured two week ago in Syria, ending the UN's fourth crisis over abducted soldiers in the Golan Heights since March 2013 amid questions about the future of its 40-year-old monitoring mission there.

item.title: Russia faces new US, EU sanctions over Ukraine crisis
item.description: European Union governments agreed on Thursday to begin their new sanctions against Russia over the Ukraine crisis on Friday but could lift them next month if Moscow abides by a fragile truce, while the United States prepared its own fresh sanctions.

item.title: US wins Arab support for Syria/Iraq military campaign
item.description: The United States signed up Arab allies on Thursday to a "coordinated military campaign" against Islamic State fighters, a major step in building regional support for President Barack Obama's plan to strike both sides of the Syrian-Iraqi frontier.

item.title: Savita Halappanavar case: Nine hospital staff members disciplined
item.description: Last November, the West/North West Hospital Group ordered a review of the actions of all staff members who treated Savita.

item.title: US, EU to intensify sanctions on Russia over Ukraine, says Barack Obama
item.description: The US and the European Union have decided to "intensify" their coordinated sanctions on Russia in the defence, finance and energy sectors as punishment for its illegal actions in Ukraine, President Barack Obama said on Thursday.

item.title: Won't take part in airstrikes on Syria: Britain
item.description: Britain's foreign secretary says his country won't participate in airstrikes on Syria, following an announcement from Washington that it would begin hitting targets inside the country.

item.title: India, Bhutan to speed up mutually agreed projects
item.description: India and Bhutan on Thursday agreed to speed up the implementation of the mutually agreed projects in this country as the two sides met here to review the Indian assistance of Rs 45 billion for Bhutan's 11th Five Year Plan.

item.title: Respect sovereignty in fight against terrorism: China
item.description: China on Thursday called for respecting sovereignty and territorial integrity of countries in the fight against terrorism, as US President Barack Obama vowed to expand airstrikes in Iraq and Syria to contain the Islamic State militants.

item.title: BJP, Congress slam UK parliament's move to hold debate on Kashmir
item.description: BJP and Congress were on the same page on Thursday as they frowned upon a proposal in Britain's House of Commons to hold a debate on the state of human rights in Kashmir.

item.title: US marks 13th anniversary of 9/11 attacks
item.description: Americans on Thursday marked the 13th anniversary of the September 11, 2001 attacks, with somber ceremonies of remembrance in New York and Washington.

item.title: EU agrees to introduce new sanctions on Russia
item.description: The European Union has decided to slap new economic sanctions on Russia over its actions in Ukraine, diplomats said on Thursday.

item.title: London: India-born nurse's royal hoax inquest opens in UK
item.description: An inquest into the death of India-born nurse Jacintha Saldanha, found hanged after she took a hoax call at a hospital here about Kate Middleton's first pregnancy, opened on Thursday after being delayed by almost a year.

item.title: Roald Dahl's 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' turns 50
item.description: Children's classic Charlie and the Chocolate Factory by British storyteller Roald Dahl, which has sold over 13 million copies worldwide, marks 50 years of publication this month and has a number of celebratory events lined up.

item.title: War gives inspiration to Gaza's artists
item.description: Palestinian filmmaker Khalil Mozayen's latest work was already complexly layered - a movie within a movie about a director and screenwriter producing a film about an honor killing in the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Lufthansa cancels 110 flights due to pilots' partial strike
item.description: Lufthansa cancelled 110 European and domestic flights due to a new round of partial strikes by its pilots based in Munich.

item.title: China shows off new missile test on prime time television
item.description: China has unveiled its latest military hardware on prime time television, an advanced air defence system that reports said has a "high success rate" destroying incoming missiles and aircraft.

item.title: Mexico small plane crash kills 5
item.description: Mysteries surround a small plane crash that killed five people in the northern state of Sinaloa.

item.title: Case thrown out against Kenya Governor linked to massacres
item.description: A Kenyan judge ended the case against the Governor of the region of Lamu, who had been arrested on allegations of links to massacres.

item.title: Ozone layer on track to recovery: UN
item.description: The Earth's protective ozone layer is well on track to recovery in the next few decades, thanks to concerted international action against ozone depleting substances, said a UN report on Wednesday.

item.title: Russia tests nuclear Bulava missile from a submarine
item.description: The Russian Navy has successfully test-launched an intercontinental ballistic missile from one of its nuclear submarines.

item.title: Displaced Iraqis brace for onset of Kurdish winter
item.description: Displaced Iraqis who escaped a jihadist-led onslaught north of Baghdad during the scorching summer are braced to face another enemy: the onset of winter in the mountains of Iraqi Kurdistan.

item.title: Australia world's most expensive for international students, India cheapest
item.description: Australia is the most expensive place for an international student to attend university, ahead of Singapore and the United States, with India the cheapest, a study showed.

item.title: New Chile bombings hit resort city
item.description: Two homemade bombs have exploded at a shopping centre in the Chilean resort city of Vina del Mar.

item.title: North America's first Islamic art museum to open in Toronto
item.description: A shiny new Islamic art museum and cultural center will open in Toronto next week, becoming the first of its kind in North America.

item.title: Snow storms hit western Canada
item.description: Snow storms battered the western Canadian city for a third day in a row, downing power lines to thousands of homes and businesses.

item.title: Ukraine says Russia withdrawing, EU delays sanctions
item.description: Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko said on Thursday that Russia had withdrawn the bulk of its forces from his country and he pledged greater automony for the separatist east in moves that could help sustain a fragile truce.

item.title: Putin promises new weapons to fend Western threats
item.description: Russia is developing an array of new nuclear and conventional weapons to counter recent moves by the US and NATO, President Vladimir Putin said on Thursday as the military successfully tested a new intercontinental ballistic missile launched from a nuclear submarine.

item.title: Indian man admits to sexually touching sleeping woman on plane
item.description: A 62-year-old Indian man has pleaded guilty to sexually touching a woman seated next to him aboard a flight, faces two years in prison.

item.title: Obama orders airstrikes in Syria for the first time to root out ISIS
item.description: Opening a new military front in the Middle East, President Barack Obama authorized US airstrikes inside Syria for the first time on Wednesday night, along with expanded strikes in Iraq as part of a broad mission to root out the violent Islamic State militants whose reign of terror has spread across both countries.

item.title: Gaza war is over, but Jerusalem violence remains
item.description: While the world's attention was focused on the airstrikes and rockets over Gaza and Israel this summer, a wave of violence hit the streets of Jerusalem - and is still roiling parts of this divided city at the core of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

item.title: John Kerry in Iraq backs government, says Baghdad a partner against Islamic State
item.description: US Secretary of State John Kerry on Wednesday endorsed Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi's plans to mend Baghdad's relations with Sunnis and Kurds, and said Iraq was a partner in the fight against Islamic State militants.

item.title: Singapore proposes 'government to government' cooperation for Andhra Pradesh capital
item.description: Singapore on Wednesday suggested a 'government to government' model of cooperation in building the new capital of Andhra Pradesh, which is proposed for inclusion in the 100 Smart Cities project.

item.title: India, Afghanistan to work hand-in-hand during critical phase
item.description: "India is here to stay," External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj today assured Afghanistan as she conveyed the new government's resolve to work "hand-in-hand" with the war-torn country by providing all possible assistance, including in key areas of defence and security.

item.title: Second British voice identified in IS 'jihadi' video
item.description: A second British voice has been identified in the disturbing video of an American hostage's beheading released by the Islamic State militants, according to a latest scientific analysis.

item.title: US drug patent expiries to benefit Indian pharma industry
item.description: Expiry of drug patents in the US is great news for not only consumers but also the domestic pharmaceutical industry, where generics account for about 75 per cent of total sales, CARE Ratings said in its report released on Wednesday.

item.title: Vistara launch may get delayed by couple of months
item.description: The launch of Vistara, the Tata-Singapore Airlines joint venture airline, may get delayed by a couple of months due to regulatory approvals, officials said on Wednesday.

item.title: UK leader rushes to fend off Scottish independence
item.description: Spooked by recent polls, Prime Minister David Cameron and other British political leaders rushed north to Scotland on Wednesday, where Cameron begged Scots not to break his heart by voting to become independent from the United Kingdom.

item.title: Debate on Kashmir in UK Parliament causes stir
item.description: A debate on the human rights situation in Kashmir to be held in the UK Parliament building on Thursday has caused a stir among Indian groups here who fear it could be used as an India bashing opportunity.

item.title: Italian Marines case: Plea filed in SC for medical examination of Latorre
item.description: A victim, who was injured in firing by two Italian Marines today approached Supreme Court pleading it not to allow one of the accused Massimiliano Latorre, who claimed to have suffered brain stroke recently, to leave the country without verifying his medical condition.

item.title: India, Afghanistan to intensify security, defence cooperation
item.description: India on Wednesday assured all possible help to the Afghan people to realise their vision of a strong, independent and prosperous Afghanistan as the two countries agreed to intensify cooperation in areas like security, defence and reconstruction work in the war-torn country.

item.title: China to launch second space lab in 2016: Official
item.description: China will launch its second orbiting space laboratory in two years' time, a top official said on Wednesday, the latest step in an ambitious space programme Beijing says will one day land a Chinese man on the moon.

item.title: Polish president commemorates WWII in Germany
item.description: Polish President Bronislaw Komorowski has commemorated the outbreak of World War II in a speech to the Germany parliament.

item.title: Australia raids Islamic centre, arrests two for jihadist links
item.description: Australian police on Wednesday raided an Islamic centre and seized two men for alleged involvement in recruiting and sending jihadist fighters to Syria.

item.title: Afghan gang rape trial badly flawed: Human Rights Watch
item.description: An Afghan court's conviction for a gang rape was wholly undermined by due process violations, Human Rights Watch said.

item.title: Water clouds found outside our solar system
item.description: A team of scientists has discovered the first evidence of water clouds on an object outside our own solar system.

item.title: Indian spared caning in Little India riots for showing remorse
item.description: An Indian in Singapore was spared caning but jailed for 25 months for his involvement in Little India riots, the country's worst violence in 40 years, as he had a clean record and showed genuine remorse for his actions.

item.title: As scots eye independence, rest of UK gets nervous
item.description: All Gavin Jones has to do is scan the shelves of his impossibly quaint shop on England's border with Scotland to know he'll have a big problem if the Scots declare independence next week.

item.title: Japanese regulator approves restart of Sendai nuclear reactor after Fukushima incident
item.description: Japan's nuclear regulator gave the go-ahead on Wednesday for the restart of a nuclear power station, the first step to reopening an industry that was mothballed after the Fukushima disaster and which may involve the definitive closure of a dozen old plants.

item.title: Gaza war is over but Jerusalem violence remains
item.description: While the world's attention was focused on the airstrikes and rockets over Gaza and Israel this summer, a wave of violence hit the streets of Jerusalem - and is still roiling parts of this divided city at the core of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

item.title: Flight MH-17 wreckage still lying in Ukraine
item.description: MH-17 had no mechanical or technical problem, likely it was struck by "high-energy objects from outside the aircraft."

item.title: Cyber threats among greatest national security dangers: US
item.description: Cyber threat is a national security danger, Obama administration has enhanced government's capabilities to address this challenge.

item.title: Guantanamo 'a living grave' for dozens cleared to leave
item.description: After more than a decade held without charge, dozens of Guantanamo detainees ought to have sight of freedom, but hard-won deals for their release are languishing awaiting a final Pentagon signature.

item.title: NATO chief hails formation of new Iraqi government
item.description: NATO head Anders Fogh Rasmussen on Tuesday welcomed the formation of the new Iraqi government.

item.title: Barack Obama appoints India-American to key administration post
item.description: Obama appoints an Indian-American to a key administration post as member of J William Fulbright Foreign Scholarship Board.

item.title: US manufacturing industry pushes India for free trade
item.description: Expressing readiness to revitalize bilateral trade relationship with India, the US manufacturing industry has appealed to Prime Minister Narendra Modi to provide foreign companies a level playing field by accepting global free trade agreement.

item.title: Barack Obama says he has authority to act against IS
item.description: Barack Obama told top lawmakers that he has the authority if he needs to take action against Islamic State militants.

item.title: Palestinian: Donors wary of funding Hamas-run Gaza
item.description: The deputy Palestinian prime minister said on Wednesday that international donors are hesitant to fund the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip so long as Hamas remains in control there and the specter of future wars looms.

item.title: Egypt to host Gaza reconstruction conference on October 12
item.description: Egypt will host a donors conference on the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip on October 12 in Cairo.

item.title: Europe readies 'space plane' for sub-orbital test flight
item.description: The European Space Agency on Wednesday put the final touches to its first-ever "space plane" before blasting it into sub-orbit for tests aimed at eventually paving the way to the continent's first space shuttle.

item.title: Massive blast hits northern Germany chemicals plant
item.description: A massive blast has rocked a chemicals plant in northern Germany, with no details yet on casualties.

item.title: Expansion of Panama Canal expected to open in 2016
item.description: Panama's President says the expansion of the Panama Canal will be completed in time to open for business in the beginning of 2016.

item.title: White House doesn't believe slain US journalist was 'sold' to Islamic State
item.description: The United States has no information indicating beheaded American journalist Steven Sotloff was "sold" to Islamic State militants by moderate Syrian opposition rebels, White House spokesman Josh Earnest said on Tuesday.

item.title: Obama to address nation, spell out policy to tackle ISIS
item.description: US President Barack Obama will address the nation on Wednesday night to spell out America's policy on ISIS terror group which has gained control over large parts of Iraq and Syria, threatening peace in the entire Middle East region.

item.title: More than half of Chinese see war with Japan 'within a few years': Poll
item.description: More than half of Chinese people think their country could go to war with Japan in the future, a new poll revealed on Wednesday, after two years of intense diplomatic squabbles.

item.title: Marriage of newlyweds, ages 96 and 95, questioned
item.description: In some ways, Rebecca Wright doesn't understand all the fuss over her 96-year-old mother's recent marriage. After all, she says, "Anybody who wants to get married must have a little dementia."

item.title: Islamic State advances in Iraq force Syria to cancel wheat deal
item.description: Syria has canceled a deal to sell 200,000 tonnes of wheat from its 2013 local crop to Iraqi private traders as conflict raging in both countries has paralysed transport of the grain, a source at Syria's state grain agency said on Tuesday.

item.title: Ebola death toll rises to at least 2,296: WHO
item.description: The death toll from the worst Ebola outbreak in history has jumped by almost 200 in a single day to at least 2,296 and is already likely to be higher than that, the World Health Organization said on Tuesday.

item.title: Myth-busting chocolate teapot developed in UK
item.description: British experts have managed to produce a chocolate teapot that held boiling water for two minutes to make a drinkable brew, busting a long-held myth.

item.title: MoS Home Rijiju to attend world reconstruction meet in Washington
item.description: Union Minister of State for Home Kiren Rijiju will attend the second World Reconstruction Conference being organised by World Bank in Washington DC from September 10 to 12.

item.title: Kate intends to have third child before she is 35: Report
item.description: Kate Middleton decided to have two children less than two years apart because she intends to have a third child before she is 35, a media report claimed on Tuesday. Friends have reportedly said that the reason why the 32-year-old Duchess of Cambridge is having two babies within less than two years is because she wants to have three by the time she is 35, The Times reported.

item.title: London: Scottish flag raised over Downing Street
item.description: Opposition Labour leader Ed Miliband has called for public buildings across the country to raise the saltire over the coming days to show their support for the 300-year-old United Kingdom.

item.title: Clarify status of facilities for higher education of child of Sri Lanka refugees born in India: HC
item.description: Madras High Court in an interim order on Tuesday directed the Director of Medical Education, to clarify the status of facilities to be provided for higher education for a child of Sri Lanka's Tamil refugees, born in India.

item.title: No discrimination in France against any community: Ambassador
item.description: The use of 'turban' by Sikh students in schools was earlier not permitted by France, which had then drawn condemnation back home in India.

item.title: Violence at home costs $8 trillion a year, worse than war: study
item.description: Domestic violence, mainly against women and children, kills far more people than wars and is an often overlooked scourge that costs the world economy more than $8 trillion a year, experts said on Tuesday.

item.title: Harsh Vardhan seeks Bangladesh PM Sheikh Hasina's support in taming vector-borne diseases
item.description: India on Tuesday sought Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina's support in combating many vector-borne diseases and providing "the highest standards of health care" to people in South Asia. "I seek your valuable support in traversing a path where we can attain the highest standards of health not only for our countries but for the entire region," Health Minister Harsh Vardhan said.

item.title: Indian scientist gets 2014 Midori prize for Biodiversity
item.description: An evolutionary Indian ecologist, Kamal Bawa has won the prestigious USD 100,000 Midori Prize for biodiversity for his pioneering research, including in climate change in the Himalayas.

item.title: First medicinal marijuana farm approved in Chile
item.description: The Chilean authorities have approved the first marijuana farm in the capital city of Santiago, but only for medicinal and research purposes.

item.title: NASA to turn ISS into perfect Earth-observing platform
item.description: In a move to monitor our planet better, NASA is adding a number of Earth-observing instruments to the International Space Station (ISS) that will increase the leverage of the orbital laboratory's unique vantage point in space.

item.title: High-energy objects penetrated MH17 before crash: report
item.description: The Boeing 777 was blown out of the sky July 17 over rebel-held territory in eastern Ukraine, killing all 298 passengers and crew on board.

item.title: British markets spooked by poll showing Scots may vote to break up UK
item.description: British financial markets tumbled on Monday after an opinion poll showed for the first time that Scots may vote for independence in a referendum next week, breaking up the United Kingdom.

item.title: Poll shows rival Scottish independence camps neck-and-neck
item.description: The rival campaigns in Scotland's fight over independence are running neck-and-neck nine days before the referendum, with a surge in support for those who wish to break away from the United Kingdom, a TNS poll showed on Tuesday.

item.title: US Iraq air raids help Kurds and Shiites at expense of Sunnis
item.description: A small group of people pick through putrefying human remains laid out on plastic sheets by the side of a road in northern Iraq, searching for any trace of missing friends and relatives.

item.title: Chile blames terrorists after bomb blast hurts 14
item.description: A blast has ripped through a fast-food restaurant next to a busy subway station in Chile's capital, injuring at least 14 people in the most damaging of nearly 30 bombings or attempted bombings in Santiago.

item.title: UN Security Council plans to suppress foreign extremist fighters
item.description: The UN Security Council plans to demand countries "prevent and suppress" the recruitment and travel of foreign fighters to join extremist militant groups like Islamic State by ensuring it is considered a serious criminal offence under domestic laws.

item.title: Obama to broaden US effort to combat terrorists
item.description: President Barack Obama will go on the offensive against the Islamic State group with a broader counterterror mission than he previously has been willing to embrace, US officials said Monday. The new plan, however, still won't commit US troops to a ground war against the brutal insurgency and will rely heavily for now on allies to pitch in for what could be an extended campaign.

item.title: Obama reaches out to Australian PM on Iraq
item.description: As part of his effort to build a global coalition against Islamic State militants in Iraq, US President Barack Obama has reached out to Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott to discuss the current situation in the war-torn country.

item.title: Fire in Brazil shantytown leaves 2,500 homeless
item.description: A huge fire destroyed around 500 homes in a shantytown in Brazil's largest city, leaving about 2,500 people homeless.

item.title: UN chief calls for more support to fight Ebola
item.description: Ban Ki- moon has called leaders of some countries to urge more support in the fight against the deadly Ebola, a spokesman said.

item.title: UN chief hails new government in Iraq
item.description: Ban Ki- moon welcomed the formation of a new government in Iraq, saying that it "is a positive step towards political stability in the country".

item.title: Canadian Navy ship buzzed by 3 Russian jets
item.description: A Canadian navy frigate taking part in a NATO exercise in the Black Sea was buzzed by three Russian military jets off the southern coast of Ukraine.

item.title: Shia outfit announces reward of Rs 1 crore on ISIS, Taliban chief
item.description: Shia outfit has announced a reward of Rs one crore each for the killing of the chiefs of ISIS, al-Qaeda, Jamaat-u-Dawa, Taliban and Harkat-ul-Mujahideen.

item.title: Ukraine's leader rallies for unity in key city
item.description: Seeking to rally national unity, President Petro Poroshenko visited a southeastern port on Monday that has been assaulted for days by Russian-backed separatists and declared the city would remain a part of Ukraine.

item.title: New dinosaur species unearthed in Tanzania
item.description: A rare discovery of dinosaur bones in Tanzania has led scientists to identify a new species of long-extinct, leaf-eating dinosaur.

item.title: John Kerry to travel to Middle East to build coalition against ISIS
item.description: John Kerry would travel to the Middle East to discuss the current situation in Iraq and build an international coalition against the Islamic State.

item.title: London's Luton airport reopens after alert
item.description: Hundreds of passengers were evacuated and flights were suspended for hours on Monday from Luton Airport near London after a suspicious package was found in a security-screening area.

item.title: Obama, Iraq's Abadi discuss Islamic State threat in call: White House
item.description: President Barack Obama phoned Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi on Monday to discuss Washington's commitment to help Baghdad's new government fight Islamic State militants, the White House said.

item.title: UK's Luton airport evacuated over suspicious item
item.description: The UK's fifth largest airport was evacuated on Monday after a security alert over a "suspicious" suitcase, disrupting flights for thousands of passengers.

item.title: Hong Kong born alumnus gives Harvard $350 million
item.description: A Hong Kong-born venture capitalist is giving Harvard University $350 million for its School of Public Health, the largest donation in the university's history, the Harvard Crimson reported on Monday.

item.title: Jihadists want to create 'house of blood': new UN human rights chief
item.description: The jihadist militants who have seized large swathes of Iraq and Syria are intent upon creating "a house of blood", the UN's new human rights chief said Monday.

item.title: Iran says Afghan, Pakistani IS volunteers arrested
item.description: Afghan and Pakistani nationals who were planning to join the ranks of Islamic State jihadists fighting in Syria and Iraq have been arrested in Iran, a government minister announced on Monday.

item.title: Al-Qaeda backs new Somali Shebab chief: statement
item.description: Al-Qaeda has backed the new Islamist chief of Somalia's Shebab insurgents after his predecessor was killed in a US air strike last week, according to a statement broadcast on Monday on Shebab radio.

item.title: EU to unveil new Russia sanctions as Ukraine truce teeters
item.description: Ukraine accused pro-Russian rebels of waging fresh attacks in the restive east on Monday, further imperilling a fragile truce as EU leaders prepared to approve punishing new sanctions on Moscow.

item.title: CIA tortured al-Qaeda suspects 'until the point of death': Report
item.description: The CIA tortured al-Qaeda suspects "until the point of death" by drowning them in water-filled baths, Britain's Daily Telegraph reported on Monday, ahead of the publication of a US Senate report on interrogation techniques.

item.title: 'God particle' could destroy the universe: Hawking
item.description: The elusive 'God particle' discovered by scientists in 2012 has the potential to destroy the universe, famed British physicist Stephen Hawking has warned.

item.title: New UN rights chief: Syria, Iraq is first priority
item.description: The Jordanian prince taking the helm of the UN's human rights office urged the world on Monday to set as its first priority bringing a halt to the gruesome and conjoined conflicts in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Killings by China anti-terror police raise concerns
item.description: When attackers from China's minority Uighurs killed 37 people in a July rampage in far western Xinjiang, police responded by gunning down at least 59 of them. When three Uighurs allegedly killed a top state-appointed Muslim cleric, police shot dead two of them. When security forces led a raid on 10 suspected Uighur terrorists, they fatally shot all but one.

item.title: Prince William and wife Kate expecting second baby
item.description: Britain's Prince William, grandson of Queen Elizabeth, and his wife Kate are expecting their second baby, Buckingham Palace said on Monday.

item.title: Meteorite smashes into Nicaraguan capital
item.description: A mysterious explosion that rocked Nicaragua's crowded capital Managua, creating a large crater, appears to have been caused by a meteorite, officials said on Sunday.

item.title: 'House' sized asteroid passes close to Earth
item.description: A 60-feet asteroid about the size of a normal house flew past Earth on Sunday posing no threat to humans, NASA reported.

item.title: Notorious serial killer Jack the Ripper 'identified' through DNA traces
item.description: Jack the Ripper, one of the most notorious serial killers in history, has been identified through DNA traces found on a shawl, claims a sleuth in a book out on Tuesday.

item.title: Thailand may ban import of hookah pipes, shisha, e-cigarettes
item.description: Thailand may stop the import of hookah pipes, shisha and e-cigarettes as they can be as harmful as cigarettes, officials said.

item.title: No evidence of al-Qaeda's presence in India: US expert
item.description: Amid a country-wide alert in India over an al-Qaeda threat, a top US counter-terrorism expert has said there is no evidence of the terror outfit's presence in the country.

item.title: Obama to reveal strategy to tackle ISIS threat on Wednesday
item.description: President Barack Obama will on Wednesday announce the US' strategy to tackle the threat posed by ISIS, the terrorist outfit which has gained control over a large part of Iraq and Syria, and has brutally killed two American journalists in recent past.

item.title: US air strikes target insurgents near Iraq's Haditha Dam
item.description: US warplanes carried out five strikes on Islamic State insurgents menacing Iraq's Haditha Dam on Sunday, witnesses and officials said, widening what President Barack Obama called a campaign to curb and ultimately defeat the jihadist movement.

item.title: Arabs vow to confront Islamic State, cooperate with international efforts
item.description: Arab League foreign ministers agreed on Sunday to take all necessary measures to confront Islamic State and cooperate with international, regional and national efforts to combat militants who have overrun swathes of Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Afghan court sentences seven men to death for gang rape in case that shook capital
item.description: Afghanistan handed the death penalty to seven men on Sunday for raping and robbing a group of women returning from a wedding in a rare case of sexual assault.

item.title: Vladimir Putin is 'self-centred', says Dalai Lama
item.description: Tibet's exiled spiritual leader the Dalai Lama criticised Russia's President Vladimir Putin as 'self-centred'.

item.title: Plane crashes in Colombia; 10 believed dead
item.description: Colombian officials say a plane crashed in a jungle region of the country and at least 10 people are believed to have died.

item.title: Britain's greatest whodunit solved with DNA analysis
item.description: The identity of the infamous British 19th century serial killer Jack the Ripper might be revealed now with the analysis of the DNA found on a cloth at a crime scene holding one of the suspects was the murderer of several prostitutes in London, a British daily reported on Sunday.

item.title: Islamic extremists grab towns in northeast Nigeria
item.description: Nigeria's Islamic extremist group, Boko Haram, has seized more towns along Nigeria's northeastern border with Cameroon and is adopting a strategy of encouraging civilians to stay, witnesses said on Sunday, as the militants pursue their new aim to carve out an "Islamic caliphate" under their black and white flag.

item.title: I would have done a better job than Obama: Mitt Romney
item.description: Former GOP presidential candidate Mitt Romney says there is no question in his mind that he would have been more effective in the White House than President Barack Obama. But he reiterates he has no plans to run again.

item.title: Somalia's al Shabaab name new leader after US strike, warn of revenge
item.description: The Somali Islamist militant group al Shabaab confirmed on Saturday that its leader Ahmed Godane had been killed in a US air strike this week and named a new leader, promising "great distress" to its enemies.

item.title: After Syria and Iraq, Islamic State makes inroads in South Asia
item.description: Islamic State pamphlets and flags have appeared in parts of Pakistan and India, alongside signs that the ultra-radical group is inspiring militants even in the strongholds of the Taliban and al Qaeda.

item.title: Obama to give speech on Wednesday on Islamic State
item.description: United States president Barack Obama will begin laying out a strategy this week to defeat Islamic State militants in the Middle East, meeting with congressional leaders on Tuesday and giving a speech on Wednesday, the eve of the 13th anniversary of the deadliest terrorist attack on US soil.

item.title: Don't put marital problems online, warns Saudi cleric
item.description: Saudi Arabia's top cleric has warned couples against publicising their marital problems online, saying such publicity could create a scandal.

item.title: Hamas rejects plan to deploy international force in Gaza
item.description: Hamas has rejected a plan by Israel's foreign ministry to deploy international troops in the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Peaches were domesticated in China, says study
item.description: You can now thank the Chinese for domesticating the fruit some 7,500 years ago, a study suggests.

item.title: Dubai lays out plans for Legoland, other parks
item.description: A property development company controlled by Dubai's ruler outlined plans on Sunday for the first phase of an entertainment and resort complex in the city that promises the Middle East's first Legoland theme park.

item.title: Nepal artificial lake bursts suddenly, no casualties
item.description: A vast artificial lake, formed after a massive landslide that blocked the Sunkoshi river in North-East Nepal last month, burst suddenly on Sunday morning.

item.title: 50 militants killed in Nigeria's Borno state
item.description: Nigerian troops on Saturday stormed a suspected hideout of Islamic militants in the north-eastern Borno state, killing over 50 members, the military said in a statement.

item.title: Palestinian president urges Hamas to yield power
item.description: The Palestinian president has threatened to dissolve a new unity government if the Hamas militant group does not give up power in the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Bahrain king praises Indian expatriates
item.description: Bahrain's King Hamad has lauded the Indian expatriate community for its contribution in pushing forward the island nation's development.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II concerned over Scotland's independence from UK
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II is very concerned that Scotland will vote for independence from the UK this month and is receiving daily updates on the situation, a media report said on Sunday.

item.title: Confront IS 'militarily and politically': Arab League chief
item.description: Arab League chief Nabil al-Arabi on Sunday called for a military and political confrontation with Islamic State jihadists and other militants he said threatened the existence of Arab states.

item.title: 10 people killed in Istanbul elevator accident
item.description: An elevator has plunged 32 stories at a construction site in Istanbul, killing ten people.

item.title: Five women terrorists facing trial in Saudi Arabia
item.description: Five female terrorists, four of them Saudi Arabian nationals, are facing trial in the Gulf nation for organising a terror group.

item.title: Myanmar cancels by-election
item.description: Myanmar's Union Election Commission on Sunday cancelled the upcoming second by-election which was scheduled for the end of this year.

item.title: Minister: 'Lot of tension' in UK coalition over visa issue
item.description: Britain's Secretary of State for Business, Innovation & Skills, Vince Cable, is scheduled to visit India next month to address the drop in visas from Indian students coming to study in British universities.

item.title: Flight MH370 mystery: Still no answers
item.description: ix months after Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 with 239 people on board disappeared in the Indian Ocean, aviation experts are still clueless over the world's greatest aviation mystery.

item.title: Iran arrests suspected nuclear plant saboteur
item.description: Iranian authorities have arrested a Ukrainian national suspected of sabotage at the country's sole nuclear power plant, an Iranian newspaper reported on Sunday.

item.title: Civilian killed in Ukraine shelling despite truce
item.description: One civilian was killed in shelling in the Ukrainian port city of Mariupol and large explosions were heard near the airport in Donetsk early on Sunday, raising fears that a cease-fire signed two days ago is on the verge of collapse.

item.title: Churches urge high court to act on gay marriage
item.description: The Mormon Church and four religious organizations are asking the US Supreme Court to intervene and settle once and for all the question of whether states can outlaw gay marriage.

item.title: Ceasefire in east Ukraine frays, woman killed by shelling
item.description: Shelling resumed near the port of Mariupol on the Sea of Azov late on Saturday night, just hours after Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian counterpart Petro Poroshenko had agreed in a phone call that the truce was holding.

item.title: Egypt arrests seven over 'gay marriage' video
item.description: The seven were arrested yesterday after appearing in a video showing two men celebrating a marriage ceremony and exchanging rings surrounded by friends.

item.title: After Syria and Iraq, Islamic State makes inroads in South Asia
item.description: Islamic State pamphlets and flags have appeared in parts of Pakistan and India, alongside signs that the ultra-radical group is inspiring militants even in the strongholds of the Taliban and al Qaeda.

item.title: Indian-origin mathematician elected new president of ICSU
item.description: Daya Reddy, an Indian-origin South African mathematician has been elected as the new president of the International Council for Science (ICSU).

item.title: UK promises Scots more powers if they reject independence
item.description: Osborne said the changes would be put into effect the moment there was a 'no' vote in the referendum.

item.title: US air strikes target militants near Iraq's Haditha Dam
item.description: It was Washington's first offensive into Iraq's western Anbar province since it started air strikes on Islamic State forces in the north of the country in August.

item.title: Sri Lanka to counter allegations at UN rights sessions
item.description: Sri Lanka, which has vowed not to cooperate with an international probe into its alleged rights abuses during the final phase of its military campaign against LTTE, will counter the charges at a UNHRC session beginning on Monday in Geneva.

item.title: China kills nearly 5,000 dogs to control rabies
item.description: Chinese authorities have killed almost 5,000 dogs after blaming five human deaths on rabies in southwestern Yunnan province.

item.title: Massive extinct volcano discovered beneath Pacific Ocean
item.description: A massive 100 million-year-old ancient extinct volcano has been discovered lurking four kilometres underwater in one of the least explored areas of the Pacific Ocean.

item.title: Islamic State beheads 2nd captive Lebanese soldier
item.description: The mother of a Lebanese soldier held captive by the militant Islamic State group says that photographs posted online purporting to show his beheading appear real.

item.title: Artillery attack challenges ceasefire in east Ukraine
item.description: Ukrainian government forces came under artillery fire late on Saturday near the strategic port of Mariupol in eastern Ukraine, in the first serious violation of a ceasefire declared only about 30 hours earlier.

item.title: Putin, Poroshenko discuss eastern Ukraine peace
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin and his Ukrainian counterpart Petro Poroshenko on Saturday discussed ways to make the new ceasefire in eastern Ukraine durable.

item.title: 2 deer tie up traffic on Golden Gate bridge
item.description: Authorities say a pair of deer on the Golden Gate bridge snarled traffic in and out of San Francisco during the evening commute.

item.title: Russia vows to react to new European Union sanctions
item.description: Russia will "certainly" react if the EU imposes new sanctions against it for allegedly "destabilising eastern Ukraine", Russia's foreign ministry said.

item.title: Libyas Islamist-backed government sworn in
item.description: Libya's Islamist-backed cabinet was sworn in on Saturday.The new cabinet is headed by Omar al-Hasi. It comprises 19 ministries and three supreme councils, Xinhua reported.

item.title: Japanese PM Shinzo Abe begins South Asia trip
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe left for Bangladesh and Sri Lanka on Saturday in a move to boost Japan's trade and investment in the counties.

item.title: Australia uranium to be used in reactors under IAEA safeguards: India
item.description: A day after it signed nuclear cooperation deal with Australia, India on Saturday said that it will used the fuel procured through this deal for reactors that are under the UN watchdog, International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards.

item.title: Mixed views in East Europe on higher NATO defense
item.description: Leaders in most Eastern European nations are just short of jubilant after NATO created a rapid-reaction "spearhead" force to protect the region from Russian bullying.

item.title: Sierra Leone to have lockdown amid Ebola crisis
item.description: A Sierra Leone government spokesman says the country is going to put the entire country into lockdown for three days later this month to try to stop the spread of Ebola.

item.title: UN chief hails initiative for dialogue in Sudan
item.description: Ban Ki- moon welcomed the initiative of holding a comprehensive national dialogue in Sudan to achieve sustainable peace.

item.title: India, Australia to strengthen ties in vocational education, training
item.description: India and Australia have come together to deepen collaboration on the skill development front with the NSDC signing a pact with Australia's Department of Industry and committing to strengthen bilateral relationship in technical vocational education and training (TVET) space.

item.title: Afghan elections: Abdullah Abdullah warns of unrest amid vote dispute
item.description: A spokesman for Afghan presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah says powerful factional supporters are pressuring the candidate to not cede any power in an upcoming meeting with his rival that could cap a five-month standoff over a disputed election.

item.title: Massachusetts jail offers $1,000-a-shot drug to fight addiction, recidivism
item.description: When William Luz's father died behind bars last month at 62 of liver failure and other illnesses tied to a lifetime of illegal drug use, his son, a former addict himself, could have dulled the pain with heroin.

item.title: Gujarat delegation visit Canada to attract investors
item.description: Preparing to host Vibrant Gujarat Global Summit in 2015, a delegation of the state recently visited Canada to explore investment opportunities and encourage partnership in education and skill development. The three-day visit of the Vibrant Gujarat delegation, led by Gujarat Resident Commissioner Bharat Lal, also focused on promoting India and Gujarat as an attractive business and knowledge destination.

item.title: South Africa requests Dalai Lama to defer visit
item.description: South Africa requested Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama to defer his visit to Cape Town for this year only.

item.title: Syrian strikes on Islamic State strongholds kill 13
item.description: Syrian airstrikes targeting a stronghold of the Islamic State extremist group, including one that struck a crowded bakery, killed at least 13 civilians on Saturday, activists said.

item.title: Hundreds gather to mourn murdered US journalist Sotloff in Miami
item.description: Hundreds of people attended a religious ceremony in Miami commemorating Steven Sotloff, the second American journalist beheaded by the Islamic State (IS) Sunni extremist organisation.

item.title: Turkish government wins vote of confidence in Parliament
item.description: The new Turkish government Saturday won a vote of confidence in parliament in capital Ankara.

item.title: Australia, Malaysia contribute $60 million each for MH370 search
item.description: An escalated underwater search operation for the missing Malaysian Airlines flight MH370 will begin in two weeks' time, with both Malaysia and Australia committing 60 million dollars each towards the effort.

item.title: Boy discovers 3000-year-old bronze sword in China
item.description: A 3000-year-old bronze sword has been discovered in a local river by an 11-year-old child in east China's Jiangsu Province. Yang Junxi discovered the rusty sword on July 2 when he was playing near the Laozhoulin River in Gaoyou County.

item.title: Merkel : Germany no place for anti-Semitism
item.description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel has called on the country's citizens to attend a rally against anti-Semitism next week in Berlin where she will be speaking.

item.title: NASA probe identifies clouds on Mars
item.description: NASA's curiosity Mars Rover identified clouds that researchers believe are most likely to have formed through the accumulation of water ice crystals.

item.title: Egypt to try Morsi for leaking secrets to Qatar
item.description: Egypt's top prosecutor says ousted Islamist President Mohammed Morsi will be tried for leaking national security secrets to Qatar during his turbulent year in office.

item.title: Myanmar muslim group rejects al-Qaeda statement
item.description: The Burmese Muslim Association (BMA) has rejected a statement by Al Qaeda leader Ayman al Zawahiri, unveiling the terror group's new focus on Myanmar, Bangladesh and India, media reported on Saturday.

item.title: Helicopter crashes in Denmark, killing at least 3
item.description: Danish police say that at least three people were killed and fourth person is missing after a small private helicopter crashed into the sea in central Denmark.

item.title: Sri Lankan fishing boat apprehended near Chennai coast
item.description: Five Sri Lankan fishermen along with their boat have been apprehended for fishing in Indian waters and 300 kg of tuna fish seized from them by the Indian Coast Guard off the Chennai coast.

item.title: 1,145 cases of dengue reported in China
item.description: Over one thousand people have been diagnosed with dengue fever in China and the government has initiated emergency measures for its prevention, authorities said on Saturday.

item.title: Seoul: North Korea again fires short-range projectiles
item.description: North Korea on Friday continued its string of rocket and missile firings, launching three short-range projectiles into the waters off its east coast ahead of a major holiday celebrated by both Koreas, a South Korean defense official said.

item.title: Ukraine, pro-Russian rebels reach ceasefire deal
item.description: Ukraine and pro-Russian rebels reached a ceasefire agreement on Friday, the first step toward ending fighting in eastern Ukraine that has caused the worst standoff between Moscow and the West since the Cold War ended.

item.title: Hillary Clinton says will decide White House run early 2015
item.description: Former US secretary of state Hillary Clinton said today she would likely decide whether she will join the 2016 presidential race by the start of next year.

item.title: US confirms death of al-Shabaab leader Godane in Somalia air strike
item.description: The Pentagon confirmed on Friday that Ahmed Godane, a founder of the al-Shabaab Islamist group, was killed in a US air strike in Somalia this week, calling it a "major symbolic and operational loss" for the al Qaeda-affiliated organization.

item.title: NATO agrees on plan to strengthen collective defence
item.description: NATO leaders on Friday agreed on a readiness action plan to strengthen the bloc's collective defence and deal with any challenge, NATO Secretary General Anders Fogh Rasmussen said.

item.title: Ukrainian government, pro-Russia insurgents sign ceasefire deal
item.description: Representatives of Ukraine's government and the pro-Russian insurgent leadership inked here Friday a ceasefire agreement slated to take effect later in the day, media reported.

item.title: South Africa has not denied visa to the Dalai Lama: Envoy
item.description: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, has not been denied a South African visa yet and the matter was still under consideration, the country's envoy said on Friday.

item.title: Ukraine, Pro-Russian rebels sign cease-fire deal
item.description: Pro-Russian rebels say on their Twitter that they have signed a cease-fire deal with Ukraine that starts in less than two hours.

item.title: Elderly woman beheaded in machete attack in UK
item.description: An 82-year-old woman of Italian origin was beheaded at her home here by a machete-wielding suspect who may have been inspired by videos of the Islamic State's recent gruesome killings of two captive American journalists.

item.title: Frankfurt: Lufthansa flights grounded in new pilots' strike
item.description: The airline promised to try and limit the impact of the strike for customers.

item.title: Five civilians killed in Iraq airstrike miss
item.description: Five civilians were killed and eight injured when warplanes missed their target on Friday in an attempted strike on the Turkish consulate in the northern Iraqi city of Mosul used as headquarters by Islamic State (IS) militants, local sources said.

item.title: Kerry, Hagel urge coalition against Islamic State
item.description: America's top diplomatic and defense leaders pressed a core coalition of 10 nations to summon the willpower to go after the Islamic State group in Iraq militarily and financially, and said they must build a plan by the time the UN General Assembly meets in about two weeks.

item.title: Ukraine set to sign peace plan with rebels
item.description: Ukraine was set on Friday to sign a Kremlin-backed truce with insurgents that could halt nearly five months of bloodshed but whose failure would unleash new Western sanctions against Russia.

item.title: Oxygen-producing life forms appeared earlier than thought: Report
item.description: Oxygen-producing life forms were present on Earth some three billion years ago - 60 million years earlier than previously thought, according to a new research on chemical weathering in ancient soil in India.

item.title: In northeast Syria, Islamic State builds a government
item.description: In the cities and towns across the desert plains of northeast Syria, the ultra-hardline al Qaeda offshoot Islamic State has insinuated itself into nearly every aspect of daily life.

item.title: $7.8 billion needed for reconstruction in Gaza
item.description: An estimated 7.8 billion dollars is needed for the Gaza Strip to reconstruct after being destroyed during the 50-day Israeli offensive on the coastal enclave, a senior Palestinian official said on Thursday.

item.title: China: Submarine captain honoured for averting an underwater 'emergency'
item.description: In a disclosure of near-disaster, China has honoured a submarine captain for averting an underwater "emergency" after his crew reportedly saved the vessel from sinking into thousands metres deep waters.

item.title: Milky Way part of newly identified galactic super cluster
item.description: A team of astronomers has demonstrated that our own galaxy, the Milky Way, is part of a newly identified ginormous super cluster of galaxies, dubbed as "Laniakea", meaning "immense heaven" in Hawaiian.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines renames bucket list promotion
item.description: Malaysia Airlines has renamed a promotional competition asking people what activities and destinations are on their "bucket list" after acknowledging it was inappropriate given the two deadly disasters it has suffered this year.

item.title: Al-Qaeda announces India wing, renews loyalty to Taliban chief
item.description: Al-Qaeda leader Ayman al Zawahri on Wednesday announced the formation of an Indian branch of his militant group he said would spread Islamic rule and "raise the flag of jihad" across the subcontinent.

item.title: Putin unveils Ukraine ceasefire plan, France halts warship
item.description: President Vladimir Putin outlined plans for a ceasefire in eastern Ukraine on Wednesday but Ukraine's prime minister dismissed the proposal, while France expressed its disapproval of Moscow's support for separatist forces by halting delivery of a warship.

item.title: Ukraine PM rejects Putin ceasefire plan as bid to deceive West
item.description: Ukraine's Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk on Wednesday rejected a ceasefire plan unveiled by Russian President Vladimir Putin as an attempt to deceive the West about Moscow's real intentions.

item.title: Central Africa attack kills at least five: Peacekeepers
item.description: At least five people were killed during an attack by armed men on a northern town in the Central African Republic, a source in the African peacekeeping force said on Wednesday.

item.title: France suspends delivery of warship to Russia
item.description: France is suspending the delivery of a hulking warship to Russia amid security concerns about Moscow's actions in neighbouring Ukraine, President Francois Hollande's office said

item.title: George W Bush's book about father titled '41'
item.description: The title of former US President George W Bush's book about his father will feature a number, not a name.

item.title: Gandhi prize for South Africa-based organization
item.description: A South Africa-based outfit involved in conflict resolution has been awarded the Mahatma Gandhi International Award for Reconciliation and Peace for its efforts in promoting peace and addressing disputes globally.

item.title: Getting help to Ebola-stricken countries to cost $600 million: UN
item.description: The cost of getting supplies needed to West African countries to get the Ebola crisis under control will be at least $600 million, Dr David Nabarro, the senior United Nations Coordinator for Ebola Disease, told reporters on Wednesday.

item.title: Starbucks sorry for not serving US woman with dog
item.description: Starbucks has apologized to a 24-year-old woman who said she was not allowed in a store because she had a service dog.

item.title: India, Russia conduct first-ever air exercises
item.description: The Indian and Russian air forces have held their first-ever military exercises involving counter-terror, fire-fighting and air defence in Russia. The 'Avia Indra-2014' India-Russia Air Exercises started on August 25 and will conclude on Thursday.

item.title: Real face of Islam is peaceful, says John Kerry
item.description: The real face of Islam is peaceful, based on dignity of all human beings and not butchers who killed American journalist Steven Sotloff a day earlier, US Secretary of State John Kerry said on Wednesday.

item.title: US girl who survived 19 stab wounds back to school
item.description: A spokesman for the girl's family says it has been a summer of doctor's appointments, surgeries, specialists and recovery. Stephen Lyons says the girl has been eager to go back to school in Waukesha. She started the 7th grade on Tuesday.

item.title: Norway: 2 killed in railway underpass explosion
item.description: Norwegian police say that two people have been killed and at least three others injured when dynamite apparently exploded accidentally during roadwork at a railway underpass.

item.title: Confusion as Ukraine, Russia announce progress towards peace
item.description: Ukraine said on Wednesday its president had agreed with Russia's Vladimir Putin on steps towards a "ceasefire regime" in Kiev's conflict with pro-Russian rebels, but the Kremlin denied any actual truce deal, sowing confusion on the eve of a NATO summit.

item.title: Barack Obama says will 'degrade and destroy' Islamic State
item.description: The United States plans to fight Islamic State until it is no longer a force in the Middle East and will seek justice for the killing of American journalist Steven Sotloff, President Barack Obama said on Wednesday.

item.title: Ready to firm up ties with India in trade, investments: China
item.description: Ahead of President Xi Jinping's visit to New Delhi later this month, China on Wednesday said that it ready to make joint effort with India to firm up cooperation in trade, investment and infrastructure.

item.title: Sushma Swaraj to visit Bahrain on Saturday
item.description: External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj will travel to Bahrain on Saturday where she is likely to seek stepped-up investment in India from the oil-rich country while highlighting wave of new initiatives taken by the new government to spur economic growth.

item.title: Egypt court bans Al Jazeera for alleged spread of 'hatred'
item.description: The court also ordered the withdrawal of licenses issued to the channel on the Egyptian Nilesat communication satellites.

item.title: US says journalist Sotloff beheading video is authentic
item.description: The United States said Wednesday that a video showing the beheading of a second US journalist by Islamic State militants is authentic.

item.title: Ukraine says Putin, Poroshenko agree on 'permanent ceasefire' in Donbass region
item.description: Ukraine's President Petro Poroshenko reached agreement with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin on Wednesday on a "permanent ceasefire" in eastern Ukraine's Donbass region, Poroshenko's press office said.

item.title: India slips to 71st rank in global competitiveness list
item.description: Weighed down by challenging economic conditions for most part of the past year, India has slipped to the 71st position -- the lowest among BRICS countries -- in an annual global competitiveness list, where Switzerland remains on top. The annual list, released on Wednesday by Geneva-based World Economic Forum (WEF), comes at a time when the new Indian government has completed 100 days in power and has promised further steps to revive its economy and the ease of doing business in the country.

item.title: 3 dead in US shooting rampage; gunman kills self
item.description: South Carolina authorities say a gunman killed two security guards and his stepfather and wounded a police officer before fatally shooting himself in the head.

item.title: Lottery to decide participants at Narendra Modi's public reception in US
item.description: A lottery system would decide the participants who would get to attend the public reception of Prime Minister Narendra Modi on September 28 at the prestigious Madison Square Garden in New York City, organisers of the event have said.

item.title: US assessing results of military action against al-Shabaab
item.description: The United States has carried out airstrikes against Al-Qaeda-linked Shebab militants in Somalia and is now assessing the results of its "operation" against the hardline militia, the White House said on Tuesday.

item.title: Barack Obama sends 350 troops to protect US Embassy in Baghdad
item.description: The US is adding 350 more troops to help protect the American Embassy in Baghdad and its support facilities in the capital, raising the number of US forces in the country to over 1,000, officials said Tuesday.

item.title: US military conducts airstrike against ISIS near Mosul Dam in Iraq
item.description: US military officials say that an airstrike against Islamic State militants in Iraq has damaged or destroyed 16 armed vehicles near the Mosul Dam.

item.title: Obama to Europe: NATO to oppose Russian aggression
item.description: Confronted by a Kremlin-backed military offensive in Ukraine, President Barack Obama and Western allies will approve plans this week to position at least 4,000 troops and military equipment in Eastern Europe, bolstering NATO's security commitments to nervous member states near the Russian border.

item.title: ISIS beheads another American journalist, releases video
item.description: White House press secretary Josh Earnest said he wasn't immediately aware of the purported Sotloff video and wasn't in a position to confirm its authenticity.

item.title: Six militants killed in US Somalia strike
item.description: Al-Shabab's top leader was in one of two vehicles hit on Monday night by a US military strike, a member of the Somali Islamic extremist group said on Tuesday. The rebel commander would not say whether Ahmed Abdi Godane, the group's leader, was among the six militants killed.

item.title: Dubai: Indian woman charged for having illegitimate child
item.description: An Indian man filed a case in a court in the UAE against his wife, who gave birth to a child in 2010 despite their not having sex for eight years, a media report said on Tuesday.

item.title: Just like 'Made in Japan', want to turn 'Made in India' into a brand: PM Modi to investors
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday tried to woo Japanese investors by assuring them there was no red tapism but red carpet in India. Giving a key note address at Japan-India Association event hosted by Jetro and Nikkei, Modi said, "Like 'Made in Japan', want to turn 'Made in India' into a brand."

item.title: Afghan talks on unity government collapse; crisis deepens
item.description: Talks on a power-sharing deal between Afghanistan's rival presidential candidates have collapsed, a top leader said on Monday, rekindling fears of ethnic unrest over disputed election results.

item.title: UN to send team to investigate Islamic State crimes in Iraq
item.description: The United Nations agreed on Monday to send investigators to Iraq to examine crimes being committed by Islamic State militants on "an unimaginable scale", with a view to holding perpetrators to account.

item.title: Pro-Russian rebels lower demands in peace talks
item.description: Pro-Russian rebels softened their demand for full independence Monday, saying they would respect Ukraine's sovereignty in exchange for autonomy - a shift that reflects Moscow's desire to strike a deal at a new round of peace talks.
