item.title: Live: India no more a land of snake-charmers, we wow the world with the 'mouse', Modi tells Japan
item.description: On the fourth day of his visit to Japan, Prime Minister Narender Modi has a long list of interaction and meeting. He started his day by interacted with students of Sacred Heart University. He will meet leaders of other political parties in Japan today. He is set to deliver a keynote address at the Japan India Association and inaugurate the Vivekanand Cultural Centre.

item.title: Poor response to Ebola causing needless deaths, says World Bank head
item.description: The world's "disastrously inadequate response" to West Africa's Ebola outbreak means many people are dying needlessly, the head of the World Bank said on Monday, as Nigeria confirmed another case of the virus.

item.title: Attached to the concept and need for women empowerment, girl child education: Modi to Japan
item.description: On the fourth day of his visit to Japan, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday interacted with students of Sacred Heart University in Tokyo and stressed on the need for women empowerment.

item.title: Israel claims West Bank land for possible settlement use, draws US rebuke
item.description: Israel announced on Sunday a land appropriation in the occupied West Bank that an anti-settlement group termed the biggest in 30 years, drawing Palestinian condemnation and a US rebuke.

item.title: Disruptive Hong Kong protests loom after China rules out democracy
item.description: China's National People's Congress (NPC) Standing Committee set the stage for a political showdown on Sunday when it rejected democrats' demands for the right to freely choose Hong Kong's next leader in 2017.

item.title: Ukraine accuses Russia of launching 'direct and open aggression'
item.description: "Direct and open aggression has been launched against Ukraine from a neighbouring state.

item.title: Narendra Modi narrates story of Hindu god Krishna to students at Japanese school
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Monday visited an elementary school in Tokyo and mingled with the students, narrating them the story of Lord Krishna.

item.title: South Korea: North Korea fires short-range projectile into sea
item.description: South Korea says North Korea has fired another short-range projectile into the sea, the latest in a slew of weapons tests the North has been conducting in 2014.

item.title: Japan aims to double India investment in 5 years: report
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will tell his Indian counterpart Narendra Modi at a summit on Monday that Japan aims to double its direct investment in India in five years from some $2 billion last year, the Nikkei business daily reported.

item.title: Australia to help anti-ISIL forces in Iraq: Tony Abbott
item.description: Australia has said that it will join its global partners including the US, UK, France and Italy to help forces resisting the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) in Iraq.

item.title: Islamist militia now guards US Embassy in Libya
item.description: An Islamist-allied militia group in control of Libya's capital now guards the US Embassy and its residential compound, a commander said Sunday, as onlookers toured the abandoned homes of diplomats who fled the country more than a month ago.

item.title: Modi visits 136-year-old school in Japan, calls himself 'the oldest student'
item.description: Keen to upgrade the educational standards in India, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Monday visited a 136-year-old school here as a "student" to understand the academic system of Japan which could be replicated back home.

item.title: Putin calls for talks on east Ukraine 'statehood'; rebels fire on ship
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin called on Sunday for immediate talks on the "statehood" of southern and eastern Ukraine, although his spokesman said this did not mean Moscow now endorsed rebel calls for independence for territory they have seized.

item.title: India, Japan to hold crucial summit talks, key agreements to be signed
item.description: On the third day of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Japan visit, crucial agreements between the two nations are likely to be signed on Monday afternoon. India and Japan are likely to agree to launch a "two-plus-two" security consultative framework involving their foreign and defence ministers during crucial summit talks between Modi and his Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe in Tokyo.

item.title: Family sorry for child who accidentally killed gun instructor
item.description: The grieving family of the Arizona gun instructor accidentally shot and killed by a girl learning to fire an Uzi submachine gun has expressed sympathy for the 9-year-old.

item.title: Oxford Dictionary reaches final definition after century
item.description: A 17-volume dictionary of medieval Latin has finally been completed by Oxford University researchers after more than a century of accumulating entries.

item.title: South Asian countries join together to combat wildlife crime
item.description: South Asian countries, including India, have endorsed a statute to develop an action plan for the next six years for working collaboratively to fight wildlife crimes.

item.title: Rona Fairhead set to be first chairwoman of BBC Trust
item.description: The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) Trust, the body overseeing the world famous news corporation, is set to get its first female head.

item.title: US welcomes proposed EU sanctions on Russia
item.description: The United States has welcomed the European Union's decision to impose fresh sanctions on Russia if it continues to escalate the conflict in Ukraine, giving it a week's time to dissipate the tensions.

item.title: Japan to work with India in finding Sickle Cell Anaemia remedy
item.description: Japan on Sunday agreed to work with India in inventing treatment to the Sickle Cell Anaemia after Prime Minister Narendra Modi sought help for finding remedy to the deadly disease commonly found among tribals in India.

item.title: Crisis with Russia close to full-scale war
item.description: Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko said on Saturday that his country is "close to the point of no return" and "point of no return is full-scale war".

item.title: Australia to fly guns and ammunition into Iraq
item.description: Australian military aircraft will fly guns and ammunition into Iraq to help fight Islamic State militants, Australia's Prime Minister said on Sunday.

item.title: Imran Khan, Qadri lead thousands of protestors to PM Sharif's house
item.description: Both Khan and Qadri have been demanding the ouster of Sharif with Khan alleging that last year's general election was rigged.

item.title: China, Tibetan exiles work towards dialogue
item.description: With over 70 representatives from 15 countries, the "Finding Common Ground" Sino-Tibetan Conference in Hamburg concluded after deciding on a dialogue between the Chinese government and the Tibetan government-in-exile to end the current impasse.

item.title: UN human rights report on Ukraine distorts facts: Russia
item.description: The latest report of office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights distorts the situation on the Russia-Ukraine border, Russia's foreign ministry said on Friday.

item.title: Don't mess with nuclear Russia, Vladimir Putin says
item.description: President Vladimir Putin said on Friday Russia's armed forces, backed by its nuclear arsenal, were ready to meet any aggression, declaring at a pro-Kremlin youth camp that foreign states should understand: "It's best not to mess with us."

item.title: Hip-hop moves as force in Missouri for slain unarmed Michael Brown
item.description: Rappers are making their voices heard in Missouri city where a white police officer killed an unarmed young black man, channeling hip-hop's earlier roots when the genre worked as a voice for the oppressed and spoke out against injustice.

item.title: China warns against foreign meddling in Hong Kong
item.description: China is issuing harsh warnings against foreign meddling in Hong Kong's politics ahead of an expected announcement recommending restrictions to the first direct elections for the leader of the Chinese-controlled financial hub.

item.title: 33-year-old slice of Princess Diana's wedding cake sold for $1,375
item.description: A 33-year-old slice of cake from Prince Charles and Princess Diana's 1981 wedding has sold at auction for $1,375.

item.title: White House digs Obama's 'suit'-able tan
item.description: The White House on Saturday strongly defended Barack Obama's dress sense after the president faced some online disapproval for wearing a more informal tan-coloured suit at a news conference on Iran and Ukraine.

item.title: 850,000 displaced in one month in Iraq: IOM
item.description: The Islamic State militants advancements have forcibly displaced 8,50,000 people in one month, the International Organisation for Migration(IOM) said on Friday.

item.title: US identifies citizens fighting for Islamic State
item.description: US intelligence and law enforcement agencies have identified around a dozen of its citizens, who have traveled to the Middle East to join jihad led by the Islamic State, officials said.

item.title: Italian PM hands out ice cream in response to magazine cover
item.description: Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi has handed out ice creams to journalists at his official residence in a lighthearted response to a cover of The Economist weekly showing him on a sinking ship, cone in hand.

item.title: Russian interference in Ukraine is intolerable: US
item.description: The United States on Saturday accused Russia of moving across the border and targeting the Ukrainian military positions.

item.title: UN watchdog tells US to curb police racism
item.description: The United States must stem police racism and brutality, a UN watchdog said on Saturday, as debate rages over the shooting of unarmed black teenager Michael Brown by a white officer in Missouri.

item.title: Ukraine seeks to join NATO; defiant Putin compares Kiev to Nazis
item.description: Ukraine called on Friday for full membership in NATO, its strongest plea yet for Western military help after accusing Russia of sending in armoured columns that have driven back its forces on behalf of pro-Moscow rebels.

item.title: Nearly 2,600 killed in east Ukraine conflict: UN
item.description: The conflict in eastern Ukraine has killed nearly 2,600 people since mid-April, the United Nations said today in their latest report, explaining the sharp increase by fighting in densely populated areas between Kiev's army and pro-Russian rebels.

item.title: Separatists say will allow "trapped" Ukrainian forces to withdraw
item.description: Pro-Moscow rebels fighting in Ukraine said on Friday they would comply with a request from the Kremlin and open up a 'humanitarian corridor' to allow the withdrawal of Ukrainian troops they have encircled.

item.title: Barack Obama says does not yet have military strategy for Islamic State
item.description: President Barack Obama said on Thursday the United States has not yet developed a strategy for confronting Islamic State in Syria, an acknowledgement that a decision had not been made on whether to launch air strikes against the militant group.

item.title: 25 Indian workers arrested in Kuwait on murder charges
item.description: 25 Indians in Kuwait have been arrested on murder charges on Friday. The External Affairs Ministry has reacted to the situation stating that India's Mission has taken up problems with Kuwaiti authorities and will soon provide necessary assistance.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines to cut 6,000 workers as part of an overhaul after MH370 and MH17 disasters
item.description: Malaysia Airlines will cut 6,000 workers as part of an overhaul announced on Friday to revive its damaged brand after being hit by double passenger jet disasters.

item.title: More than three million Syrians registered as refugees: UN
item.description: The UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) on Friday announced that over three million Syrians have been registered as refugees and the crisis is only getting worse, BBC reported.

item.title: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott to visit India, Malaysia
item.description: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott announced on Friday that he will travel to India and Malaysia next week.

item.title: Massive solar flare can damage communications on Earth
item.description: The most powerful solar flare ever is beginning to rotate to a position directly in line with Earth that, if it hits the ground, can send GPS and communication signals out of gear, the NASA reported.

item.title: Libya's interim government resigns under pressure
item.description: Libya's toothless interim government, led by Prime Minister Abdullah al-Thani, announced it had tendered its resignation to the elected parliament, days after a rival Islamist administration was created.

item.title: Russia responsible for violence in eastern Ukraine: Barack Obama
item.description: Blaming Russia for the escalating violence in eastern Ukraine, US President Barack Obama has said that Moscow was deliberately and repeatedly violating the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine.

item.title: Colombia court allows lesbian adoption
item.description: Colombia's Constitutional Court has ruled that a lesbian woman could adopt her long-time partner's daughter, though the ruling does not apply to gay adoption in all circumstances.

item.title: Russia responsible for violence in eastern Ukraine: Obama
item.description: Blaming Russia for the escalating violence in eastern Ukraine, US president Barack Obama has said that Moscow was deliberately and repeatedly violating the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine.

item.title: More than 1,000 Russian troops operating in Ukraine: NATO
item.description: The alliance released satellite images it said showed Russian combat forces, armed with heavy weapons, engaged in military operations inside Ukrainian territory.

item.title: Malaysia signs MoU with Australia for MH370 search
item.description: Malaysia has signed a deal with Australia to strengthen their collaboration for searching the ill-fated Malaysian flight MH370, which disappeared midair over five months ago with 237 people aboard.

item.title: Ebola epidemic to get worse: Health official
item.description: The Ebola outbreak in West Africa will get worse before it gets better, said a top public health official, the BBC reported on Thursday.

item.title: Australia to help US in Iraq air strikes
item.description: Australia has expressed willingness to contribute its Super Hornet fighter jets to help US-led air strikes in Iraq.

item.title: US journalist's mother pleads with ISIS for kidnapped son's release
item.description: The mother of a US hostage who has been threatened with death by jihadist terrorists pleaded for his life on Wednesday amid mounting fears for Americans captured in Syria.

item.title: Barack Obama to travel to China Burma and Australia in November
item.description: US President Barack Obama will visit China, Burma and Australia in November as part of his administration's Asia Pacific re-balance strategy to attend key regional summits and meet G-20 leaders, a senior US official said.

item.title: New counter-terrorism units at Australian airports
item.description: New counter-terrorism units have been working at Australia's two largest airports since last week and had already intercepted a person of interest, the prime minister said Wednesday.

item.title: Islamic State executes soldiers, takes hostages at Syria base: social media
item.description: Islamic State militants have executed Syrian army soldiers and are holding a group hostage after capturing an air base in northeast Syria at the weekend, pictures posted on social media by supporters showed on Wednesday.

item.title: IMF's Christine Lagarde put under investigation in French fraud case
item.description: IMF chief Christine Lagarde has been put under formal investigation by French magistrates for alleged negligence in a political fraud affair dating from 2008 when she was finance minister.

item.title: London: Indian teachers asked to enter $1 million prize
item.description: A global education foundation has called upon Indian teachers to enter the USD 1 million Global Teacher Prize to be presented to an exceptional teacher who has made an outstanding contribution to the profession.

item.title: North Korea calls US 'human rights graveyard' over Ferguson
item.description: North Korea has joined the ranks of America's foes who have seized on riots in Missouri, saying the nation is the "graveyard of human rights" and should mind its own business rather than criticise others.

item.title: Boko Haram seizes town on Nigeria, Cameroon border: police
item.description: Boko Haram has seized control of a Nigerian town after soldiers deployed there fled to take refuge across the border in nearby Cameroon, a police source said on Wednesday.

item.title: Seven countries join US in arming Kurds against ISIL
item.description: Seven countries, including Italy, France and the UK, have joined the American effort to arm the Kurdish forces in northern Iraq against Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS), a terrorist outfit that has gained control of large parts of Syria and Iraq.

item.title: WHO urges stiff regulatory curbs on e-cigarettes
item.description: The World Health Organization (WHO) called for stiff regulation of electronic cigarettes as well as bans on indoor use, advertising and sales to minors, in the latest bid to control the booming new market.

item.title: Gaza ceasefire takes hold as focus turns to longer term
item.description: A ceasefire between Israel and the Palestinians aimed at ending their seven-week conflict in Gaza appeared to be holding early on Wednesday as the focus shifted to securing an arrangement for the long term.

item.title: Singapore to boost cyber security efforts
item.description: Singapore's Infocomm Development Authority will set up a monitoring and operations control centre to help the government guard against, and respond swiftly, to security threats, the government announced on Tuesday.

item.title: WHO shuts Sierra Leone lab after worker infected with Ebola
item.description: The World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday that it had shut a laboratory in Sierra Leone after a health worker there was infected with Ebola, a move that may hamper efforts to boost the global response to the worst ever outbreak of the disease. At least 1,427 people have died and 2,615 have been infected since the disease was detected deep in the forests of southeastern Guinea in March.

item.title: US plane diverted as passengers fight over seat reclining
item.description: A flight from Newark to Denver was diverted to Chicago after a mid-air brawl erupted when a man set up a gadget that would not let the woman in front of him recline in her seat and she tossed a cup of water in his face.

item.title: Israel, Palestinians reach Gaza ceasefire deal: Hamas spokesperson
item.description: Israel and the Palestinians have reached a Gaza ceasefire deal and an official announcement will be made in Egypt, where the agreement was mediated, a Gaza-based Hamas spokesman said on Tuesday.

item.title: Illegal arms sale: SC voices anguish over Armymen being let off with reprimand
item.description: The Supreme Court on Tuesday expressed its anguish over top-ranking Army officers being let off with minor punishment of "reprimand" and small fine for their involvement in illegal sale of weapons and kept its option open to order probe in all Army commands.

item.title: Authorities in UK suspect James Foley's killer to be British
item.description: Authorities in the UK suspected US journalist James Foley's killer to be British because of his accent in the execution video. Ross Patel, Forensic Expert) "There's definitely a change of actor. The changing of the seek, of the individual standing next to the deceased. There are noticeable, there are subtle but there are also noticeable changes in their build, their physical appearance, the dimensions of the knife, the style of the knife that is used."

item.title: Mourners urge black Americans to take action
item.description: The mourners filled an enormous church to remember Michael Brown - recalling him as a "gentle giant," aspiring rapper and recent high school graduate on his way to a technical college.

item.title: UN chief asks India-Pakistan to resolve issues through dialogue
item.description: UN chief Ban Ki-moon has asked India and Pakistan to resolve their issues peacefully and through dialogue, against the backdrop of cancellation of foreign-secretary level talks between the two nations and continued ceasefire violations by Pakistan along border posts.

item.title: Rare copy of Superman comic book fetches US dollar 3.2 million
item.description: A nearly flawless copy of Superman's comic-book debut has sold for a super-powered price US dollar 3.2 million.

item.title: Israeli air strikes kill two Palestinians, 20 wounded
item.description: Israeli air strikes launched before dawn on Tuesday killed two Palestinians and destroyed much of one of Gaza's tallest apartment and office buildings, setting off huge explosions and wounding 20 people, Palestinian health officials said.

item.title: UN accuses Islamic State of mass killings
item.description: The United Nations condemned on Monday "appalling, widespread" crimes by Islamic State forces in Iraq, including mass executions of prisoners that could amount to war crimes.

item.title: Shooter injured self, no one else on Virginia base: US Army
item.description: A soldier with a gun inside a major command's headquarters turned the weapon on herself, causing an injury, but didn't wound any others as a heavily trafficked Virginia Army base temporarily went on lockdown on Monday morning.

item.title: US: All clear at Army base after active shooter report in Virginia
item.description: The all clear has been given at Fort Lee Army base in Virginia after an active shooter was reported there. Army officials said the base was on lockdown and personnel were told to enact active shooter protocols.

item.title: Vietnam seeks India's help on CBSE pattern in schools
item.description: Vietnam on Monday sought cooperation from India to bolster its primary school education even as CBSE textbooks are slowly gaining popularity. During External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj talks with the Vietnamese leadership, it was noted that India has a good primary school system.

item.title: US: Active shooter reported at Army base in Virginia
item.description: An active shooter has been reported at the Fort Lee Army base in central Virginia.

item.title: US boy suspended, arrested for writing about killing dinosaur
item.description: In a bizarre incident, a 16-year-old high school boy in the US was suspended and arrested for writing about killing his neighbour's pet dinosaur using a gun in an assignment.

item.title: Indian national found murdered in Singapore industrial estate
item.description: A 26-year-old Indian national was found murdered near his workplace in the industrial estate of Pandan on the west coast of Singapore, on Monday.

item.title: 3 beheaded in southern Brazil prison riot
item.description: Three prisoners were beheaded and at least five other people were injured in a riot that erupted in a southern Brazilian prison, authorities said.

item.title: Hurricane Marie grows stronger in Pacific ocean
item.description: Hurricane Marie has grown in strength as it moves out into the Pacific, reaching Category 4 status and provoking dangerous waves along Mexico's western coast.

item.title: Family of James Foley celebrates his life, prays for hostages
item.description: The family of murdered US journalist James Foley prayed for the safety of his fellow hostages as hundreds had gathered for a mass to celebrate his life as a witness on the front line.

item.title: China targets ordinary Uighurs with beards, burkas
item.description: Outside a mosque in China's restive west, a government-appointed Muslim cleric was dodging a foreign reporter's question about why young men of the Uighur ethnic minority don't have beards when one such youth interrupted.

item.title: More than 250 migrants may have died in shipwreck off Libya
item.description: More than 250 migrants may have died when a boat sank a kilometre (half a mile) off the Libyan coast, a coastguard official said on Sunday.

item.title: Ebola hits west African economy; fields, mines abandoned
item.description: The epidemic has ravaged the region since it erupted in the forests in the south of Guinea earlier this year, killing 1,427 people and infecting thousands more.

item.title: Qatar denies funding extremist Islamic State group
item.description: The Gulf nation of Qatar is hitting back at suggestions that it supports the Islamic State extremist group, saying that "determined, collective action" is needed to end sectarian violence gripping Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Strong California quake causes injuries, damage historic buildings
item.description: The largest earthquake to hit the San Francisco Bay Area in 25 years sent scores of people to hospitals, ignited fires, damaged multiple historic buildings and knocked out power to tens of thousands in California's wine country on Sunday.

item.title: Israeli airstrike collapses Gaza apartment tower
item.description: Israel bombed an apartment tower in downtown Gaza City on Saturday, collapsing the 12-story building in an unprecedented strike, while Hamas kept up heavy rocket fire that sent more Israelis fleeing border areas close to Gaza.

item.title: NASA satellite to help farmers combat drought
item.description: NASA scientists, including one of Indian-origin, have developed a new satellite than can predict the severity of droughts worldwide and help farmers maximise crop yield.

item.title: Strong 6.4-magnitude quake jolts central Chile: USGS
item.description: A strong 6.4-magnitude earthquake has jolted central Chile, officials said, though there were no immediate reports of fatalities or serious damage.

item.title: Egypt calls for Gaza ceasefire as fighting rages
item.description: Egypt called on Israel and the Palestinians on Saturday to halt hostilities and resume peace talks, but both sides kept up attacks, including an Israeli air strike which destroyed a residential tower block in the center of Gaza City.

item.title: Obama orders review of police use of military hardware
item.description: US President Barack Obama has ordered a review of the distribution of military hardware to state and local police out of concern at how such equipment has been used during racial unrest in Ferguson, Missouri.

item.title: MH17 bodies returned as Malaysia battles fallout
item.description: Carried by soldiers and draped in the national flag, coffins carrying Malaysian victims of Flight MH17 returned home Friday to a country still searching for those onboard another doomed jet and a government battling the political fallout of both tragedies.

item.title: 18-year-old British Indian hailed as brainiest student in Britain
item.description: An 18-year-old British Indian boy has become Britain's brightest student after getting perfect fives in all major subjects with 100 per cent score, a media report said.

item.title: Europe's Galileo satellites launched into wrong orbit
item.description: European satellite launch company Arianespace announced on Saturday that the two satellites of Europe's Galileo satellite navigation system launched on Friday from the European spaceport in French Guiana were delivered into the wrong orbit.

item.title: Over a hundred migrants missing after boat sinks off Libyan coast
item.description: A wooden boat carrying up to 200 migrants has sunk just one kilometre (half a mile) off the Libyan coast, the coast guard said on Saturday, and most passengers were feared drowned.

item.title: 35,000 Nepalese attempt to set world's largest human flag record
item.description: In a bid to set a new world record, over 35,000 Nepalese on Saturday gathered at an open ground to form the world's largest "human national flag".

item.title: Ebola spreads in Nigeria; Liberia has 1,000 cases
item.description: Two alarming new cases of Ebola have emerged in Nigeria, widening the circle of people sickened beyond the immediate group of caregivers who treated a dying airline passenger in one of Africa's largest cities.
